Definition: You have been given a comment from some user from the dataset of civil comment, categorize the comment on the basis of toxicity of the comment. If the comment is toxic output Yes, else output No.

Positive Examples.input: haha you guys are a bunch of losers.
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment here has word 'losers', which is used as an attack on a subject in the comment. Hence, it is a positive example

Positive Examples.input: Is this something I'll be able to install on my site? When will you be releasing it?
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment is just a query with no derogatory or toxic attacks and connotations. Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.input: You just linked to a complaint (not a court case, a complaint - there is a huge difference) by a guy trying to not pay his taxes.  Incidentally, his complaint and associated arguments were rejected by the Tax Court, by the U.S. District Court, by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals and denied certiorari by the U.S. Supreme Court.  In other words, literally nobody agreed with him, and he found out the hard way that living in Texas makes him a citizen of Texas and the United States, which obligates him to pay his damn taxes like the rest of us.Just because someone crams a bunch of words, statutes, and case law citations together in a document sprinkled with lawyerly language does not make it a legitimate or lawful argument.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment does not have any explicit curses or derogatory words in it. The word 'damn' negative tone but not used as an attack on anything. Therefore, this is a negative example.

Negative Examples.input: Apologies.  Her name is Hasselberger.  As far as I can tell, she will neither be in Guam or a part of the proceedings.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment doesn't have any curse words in it, however it is toxic because based on subject's name 'Hasselberger' a toxic judgement has been made. Therefore, this is a negative example.

This is  an ideal spot to place 40ft shipping containers as apartments. 1st cut a large hole (big enough to drive a car thru) in the middle. Weld the doors at the end closed. Weld a set of steel bunk beds in the far ends. Weld a set of lockers next to the beds. Add a steel table and chairs. If you have to use lag bolts than weld the heads of the lag bolts. These have to be crowbar proof and sledge hammer resistant. Finally weld a steel bar one foot down from the top by the opening in the container (for ventilation) and hang a blanket or drapes for privacy. Each container will provide two apartments for two occupants each. Most contractors could provide these for about $5,000-$10,000 each. But the city of Portland would insist on paying 100's of thousands of dollars each. Just look at how much they spent on the two storage containers for homeless daytime storage use, ($226,000) each!

Hello, JP:  My 4 samples were intended to let you know where I was 'coming from'.  As noted, unlike in the surveys you cite, I haven't seen 3/4 quarters of respondents waxing lyrical and swooning over their encounters with the Canadian healthcare system.  That's all that I was saying.

"...my training is in stats..."   That's great!  Then you understand v. well how push-polling works, and how you frame a question to the general populace will heavily influence the kind of answer you get.  :-/  Right?

"...Canada spends 55% of what we spend..."  The huge flaw in the surveys you cite is the assumption that all healthcare delivery operates under the same conditions, country to country.  It doesn't.  Canada and Great Britain don't have our screwy tort system.  Most of the additional costs for us are, effectively, lawsuit insurance.  :-/  Which is one reason I don't see single-payer coming to the U.S. - the TLA won't allow it (unless they can sue the government for unlimited amounts).
